question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Given $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},$ compute
\[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\]
inference:
$\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} (1)(1) - (0)(0) \\ (0)(0) - (2)(1) \\ (2)(0) - (1)(0) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.$
$\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.$
$(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} (-2)(-3) - (0)(-2) \\ (0)(1) - (1)(-3) \\ (1)(-2) - (-2)(1) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.$
$\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} (0)(-3) - (1)(-2) \\ (1)(1) - (0)(-3) \\ (0)(-2) - (0)(1) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.$
$\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} (1)(0) - (0)(1) \\ (0)(2) - (2)(0) \\ (2)(1) - (1)(2) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.$
$(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.$

Final Answer: $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
We have that
\begin{align*}
(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} &= \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
\end{align*}and
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right) \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.
\end{align*}Hence,
\[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]The main point of this exercise is to illustrate that in general,
\[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} \neq \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\]In other words, the cross product is not associative.

$\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} (1)(0) - (0)(1) \\ (0)(2) - (2)(0) \\ (2)(1) - (1)(2) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.$

inference:
Let $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$, $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$, and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$.

We first compute $\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}$:
$$\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} (1)(1) - (0)(0) \\ (0)(0) - (2)(1) \\ (2)(0) - (1)(0) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.$$
Then we compute $(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c}$:
\begin{align*} (\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} (-2)(-3) - (0)(-2) \\ (0)(1) - (1)(-3) \\ (1)(-2) - (-2)(1) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}
Next, we compute $\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}$:
\begin{align*} \mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c} &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} (0)(-3) - (1)(-2) \\ (1)(1) - (0)(-3) \\ (0)(-2) - (0)(1) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}
Then we compute $\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c})$:
\begin{align*} \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} (1)(0) - (0)(1) \\ (0)(2) - (2)(0) \\ (2)(1) - (1)(2) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}
Finally, we compute $(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.$

Final Answer: $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}$
ground_truth:
We have that
\begin{align*}
(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} &= \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
\end{align*}and
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right) \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.
\end{align*}Hence,
\[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]The main point of this exercise is to illustrate that in general,
\[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} \neq \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\]In other words, the cross product is not associative.
